caseTitle: T H E R E P U B L I C v NANA OSEI BONSU ll, MAMPONGHENE
summary: This Supreme Court of Ghana case arose from a chieftaincy dispute over the installation of Nana Yaa Adwubi as Mamponghemaa (queenmother) of Asante Mampong. The appellants, supporters of a rival nominee, obtained an injunction from the Ashanti Regional House of Chiefs to restrain the installation, but the respondents proceeded with the enstoolment on 29 February 2000. The High Court convicted the respondents for contempt, but the Court of Appeal overturned the conviction. The Supreme Court upheld the Court of Appeal's decision, holding that the enstoolment had already occurred on 7 February 2000—prior to the injunction—based on affidavits from key traditional authorities (Krontihene, Akwamuhene, Abusuapanin) who affirmed that the customary process in Asante Mampong was complete upon nomination, acceptance, and public introduction. The Court rejected the appellants' claim that physical seating and regalia transfer were essential, citing Republic v Sito l; Ex parte Fordjour. It also found that the trial judge erred in relying on Nana Afua Saka’s affidavit, which was discredited by evidence showing she had ceased to be acting queenmother in 1994, not 2000. The Supreme Court emphasized that customary law varies by community and must be determined by credible local authorities, affirming that the respondents’ actions did not constitute contempt.
verdict: Appeal dismissed; decision of the Court of Appeal allowing the appeal against contempt conviction is upheld.
winningSide: Respondents (Nana Osei Bonsu II, Busuapanin Alex Osei Bonsu, and Nana Yaa Adwubi)
citations: Republic v Sito l; Ex parte Fordjour [2001-2002] SCGLR 322
rationaleHighlights: Customary law is community-specific under art. 11(3) of the 1992 Constitution.
Enstoolment may be valid even without physical seating on a stool or possession of regalia.
Affidavit evidence from traditional authorities outweighed uncorroborated claims.
Trial court erred in relying on discredited witness who falsely claimed prior acting role.
Court of Appeal correctly overturned contempt conviction due to insufficient proof.
